Thanks for your question! Great point about affordability—we totally get it! 😊

Our compost starter is a custom blend designed specifically for optimal performance in our Airthereal electric composter. It helps kickstart the breakdown process efficiently, reduces odors, and accelerates decomposition, especially in the heat and dry conditions of an electric composter. While it’s not something you’ll find off the shelf, we’ve worked hard to keep costs reasonable while ensuring the best results.
That said, if you're exploring alternatives, here are some key things to consider when choosing a compost starter for an electric composter:
1. Heat-Resistant Microbes – Since electric composters use heat to speed up decomposition, choose a starter with thermophilic (heat-loving) microbes that can survive in warm, dry conditions.
2. Low Moisture Sensitivity – Many traditional compost starters work best in outdoor, high-moisture conditions. For electric composters, look for microbes that remain active in drier environments.
3. Bokashi Bran or EM (Effective Microorganisms) – Bokashi bran contains beneficial microbes that aid decomposition, though it works best in anaerobic (low-oxygen) environments, so results may vary.
4. Enzyme-Based Starters – Some compost starters use enzymes to break down food waste faster, making them a good fit for electric composters with short cycles.
5. Odor Control & Eco-Friendliness – A good starter should help minimize smells and be made from natural, non-toxic ingredients.

Many customers with our previous-generation composters have experimented with products like Jobe’s Organics Compost Starter. While Jobe’s is great for traditional composting, it’s not specifically designed for the heat and dryness of electric composters. It works better as a finishing touch after the composting process rather than during it.

We’re always looking at ways to improve accessibility and affordability, so your feedback is super helpful! If bulk options or alternatives become available in the future, we’ll be sure to update everyone. Let us know if you have any other questions—we’re happy to help!

Why are shipping fees so high for such a small item? 😳
For all couriers, the shipping cost of lighter products makes up a higher proportion of the product value.
Couriers like UPS often charge more for the 1.5kg range than the 3kg range in most countries. Even so, we choose UPS when the cost in specific countries is cheaper than other couriers.

I see the device has HDMI built-in, but can you connect to additional external monitors via USB-C. I have a dual monitor setup, and use a USB-C dock to enable the dual setup, so can this also be accomplished with this device?
Hi Steve，
Bapaco does indeed have an HDMI port built-in, and you can absolutely connect to additional external monitors via USB-C as well.

Bapaco supports DisplayPort 1.4 Alt Mode over USB-C, which means you can use a USB-C to DisplayPort cable or a USB-C hub with DisplayPort output to connect to another monitor. This allows you to extend your workspace across multiple screens, just like you're used to with your current USB-C dock setup.
So, with Bapaco, you can have a multi-monitor setup with:
One monitor connected via HDMI.
One or more monitors connected via USB-C (using appropriate adapters or hubs).
This makes Bapaco a versatile productivity tool for those who rely on multiple displays for their workflow.
Hi Stephen!
Thanks so much for backing Bapaco and for your kind words! We're really excited to get Bapaco into your hands.
To answer your questions:

Linux OS (or installing your own OS): You absolutely can install your own operating system, including Linux! Bapaco is designed with customization in mind, and you'll have full access to the BIOS and boot settings to install your preferred OS.

To make this even easier (and more cost-effective!), we recommend considering our package without pre-installed RAM and ROM. This allows you to source your own components and install your preferred Linux distribution from scratch.

Thunderbolt (for eGPU): Unfortunately, Bapaco does not currently support Thunderbolt. We understand the need for high-bandwidth connectivity for tasks like AI/ML with eGPUs. We'll keep Thunderbolt support in mind for future versions of Bapaco, as we continue to explore ways to enhance performance and connectivity.
We appreciate your support and valuable feedback! If you have any more questions, please don't hesitate to ask.
Best regards,
The Bapaco Team

Hi Daniel,
That's a great question! The functionality available depends on how you're connecting the external device and which operating system is active.
When using Bapaco's built-in Windows OS:
USB 2.0, USB 3.0, and USB-C ports: These ports function as normal, allowing you to connect peripherals like mice, keyboards, external drives, etc.
HDMI port: You can use this to connect an external monitor and extend or mirror Bapaco's display.
SSD: This is Bapaco's internal storage, used by the Windows OS.
When connecting an external device (Mac, Windows, or Android) to Bapaco:
Display: Bapaco's screen acts as a display for the external device, mirroring its operating system and interface.
Input: Bapaco's keyboard and touchpad can be used to control the external device.
USB ports: The functionality of these ports depends on the external device and its operating system. Generally, they should work as normal for connecting peripherals.
Internal components: Bapaco's internal components, such as the HDMI port, SSD, are typically not shared with the external device.

Hi Erik，
Thank you for your interest in our ChargeUltra 2 charger. We're glad you inquired about its compatibility with your devices.

The ChargeUltra 2 is compatible with your Galaxy Fold 5 when used with a MagSafe case. The MagSafe technology in your case enables seamless wireless charging with our charger, ensuring a hassle - free and efficient charging process.

However, regarding your Galaxy Watch 6, our ChargeUltra 2 has a dedicated watch - charging area that is specifically designed to work with Apple Watches. It is not directly compatible with the Galaxy Watch 6. If you also own an Apple Watch, you can use that charging area for it. But for the Galaxy Watch 6, you'll need to use the charging device provided by Samsung for optimal charging performance.
We hope this information clarifies the compatibility details for you.
Best
Will this have any heat dissipation for the Q charging phone?

Hi there! Thank you for your question. Our ChargeUltra 2 is designed with user convenience and device safety in mind. The magnetic side of the charger is equipped with a high - quality heat - dissipating silicone pad. This pad plays a crucial role in efficiently dissipating heat generated during the Qi - charging process.

When your phone is charging wirelessly, heat is an inevitable by - product. Our heat - dissipating silicone pad helps to draw the heat away from the charging area of your phone, ensuring that your device remains at a safe operating temperature. This not only helps to protect your phone's battery and internal components from potential heat damage but also contributes to a more stable and efficient charging experience. So, you can rest assured that your Qi - charging phone will be well - taken care of when using our ChargeUltra 2. If you have any other questions, feel free to reach out.

Hi Ken, we have to clarify that the external backup battery is indeed included in the super early bird, but it is 16280 850mAh. 16280 Lithium Battery It is a common lithium-ion battery model, 16280: indicates the size of the battery, where 16 means that the battery diameter is 16mm and 280 means that the battery length is 28.0mm.
We don't think there is other special name for it. You can find the right battery in the US in the following ways:
1. You can directly search for “16280 lithium battery” or “16280 battery” on US e-commerce platforms such as Amazon, eBay, etc.

2. If you can't find the exact same model, you can look for an alternative model with similar dimensions, same voltage in 3.7V, and similar capacity. For example, 18650 lithium batteries are another common model, and are slightly larger than 16280 batteries. And you can get one to try on this light.
Hopefully this information will help you find the right battery.

I don't think there's any problem having USB 2.0 regardless of how old it is. As far as its use as a book scanner the 480 Mbps is more than enough to handle full size images faster than a person can switch pages. As far as its use for streaming, 480 Mbps is far faster than the recommended upload bitrate for any platform. USB 2.0 is not the problem. Changing to an port with a faster speed would not affect performance at all and would only serve to make some users feel better while increasing the cost. The change could also require changing chips on the board to ones that could handle the increased speed, which could also require redesigning the board to meet increased power needs.

USB-C may be helpful as it is becoming the standard. Most Windows laptops still have USB-A ports but Apple has been eliminating them in their latest models. If USB-C were implemented in this model I think the USB 2.0 version would be more than adequate. If it were changed I imagine other users would complain since USB-A is still in wide use and may be the only unused USB ports on their device. Desktops still tend to have more USB-A ports than USB-C. Whichever connector is used there will be people requiring an adapter.

For those that want to use it for streaming presentations I think the main limiting factor is whatever processor is used. The video format is MJPG, which is very high quality but isn't very suitable for streaming due to its large file size. It isn't compressed much so it requires little processing power to encode. Since the primary purpose is scanning books, I'm guessing they selected a processor well suited to that task. They do include an HDMI 1.4 port. For users who want a better streaming experience a good option would be using an HDMI capture device. That would let you get up to 4Kp30. The processing would be offloaded to the capture device or your computer without imposing a higher cost on all the users who just want to use it as a book scanner. If they find one that works well maybe it could be offered as an addon and they could get a bulk discount. Maybe it could be a stretch goal.
(Not the same Alex that commented on USB ports earlier)

In the near future, I plan to replace the GM tube with a signal generator to check the limitations of the PCB and program.
So is it TSA compliant for travel in an aircraft

A Geiger counter, which is used to detect and measure ionizing radiation, is generally not prohibited by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) for carry-on or checked baggage. The Doze with a 400mAh battery should generally be safe to bring through TSA security. However, it's always a good idea to check the latest TSA guidelines and your airline's policies before traveling.
If you have any other questions, kindly let us know any time.
We're hard at work behind the scenes and can’t wait to share our next updates with you. The next one is coming this weekend - stay tuned!
If you have any further questions, reach out to us.
Is there an "accumulated dose" feature in firmware? IMHO it is the most usable feature for this kind of EDC gadget.

Doze measures the accumulated dose from the moment you switch it on (or when you reset the timer via a button press). If the dose or dose rate exceeds the defined limit, an alarm occurs. Additionally, Doze measures the peak rate and records the time it was measured, enabling the user to recall where it happened. Another feature is that Doze measures the average dose rate. We find this particularly helpful when measuring small differences in radiation between various objects or environments.
Regarding custom fees, from what country device will be sent to us?

We wanted to let you know that we're handling shipments for our European Backers from Germany. We may take a different approach for other continents, depending on what makes sense in terms of time and cost.

As you do not provide device schematic, is there a chance that I can physically damage circuit board when modifying firmware, e.g. by accidentally increasing high voltage generator output level? Is high voltage generator managed by Attiny or is it an independent circuit?

We do not see a way to damage the PCB board by changing the firmware. The high voltage unit is a separate circuit and can only be switched on and off by the controller. We will add detailed comments to the firmware to guide programmers through the code.
What development environment do you use to program Attiny?
We are using the Arduino IDE and the Micronucleus bootloader. If you have any other questions or need assistance, feel free to reach out!
We wanted to let you know that we do provide the print files for the case and the programming code for Doze. Unfortunately, we can't share the schematic design files for the complete device.
What Geiger counter tube do you use?
Thank you for your interest. We are using a J707 Tube with a diameter of Ø5±1mm and a total length of 18±3mm.
So it is a low-sensitivity gamma detector, most usable in doomsday scenarios.
For those interested in exact numbers, see a good Chinese Geiger tube comparison table in "reply #29" here:
If you like please take a moment to watch our test run video to see how Doze reacts to an opened sensor of an ionization chamber smoke detector containing americium-241.
Why did you choose a GM tube over a scintillation crystal?

Thank you for supporting our project. The use of a GM tube has been central to our vision for Doze from the very beginning, which is why we didn't decide for alternative solutions. This choice stems from personal reasons: we all learned about the GM tube's measuring principle in school, we're fans of novels and games like Metro, and we loved the idea of featuring the GM tube as a visible design element in Doze.
Scintillation crystal costs times more than Doze device itself.

@Wekos thank you for your clear explanation on why you chose the GM tube!

Thank you for your question! We appreciate your curiosity.

Regarding the one-year battery timeframe: Doze enters sleep mode in the Lifeguard configuration (display off, controller in sleep mode). In this state, Doze consumes only a few microamperes (μA) in the double-digit range, which means that a 400 mAh battery can last more than one year. Despite being in sleep mode, Doze continues to measure. Whenever a particle is detected, it wakes up, logs the measurement, and then returns to sleep mode.

Doze can measure the radiation levels of food, though not as accurately as specialized devices. This is because it also accounts for the ambient radiation in your surroundings. To obtain precise radiation levels in food, complex measurements are required to determine whether -and to what extent- a food item is contaminated with radioactivity. First, food samples must be prepared in a specific manner and protected from external influences. Then, measurements are conducted using specialized devices that are far more accurate and sensitive than a Geiger counter. Such devices are typically found only in specialized facilities.
We will be uploading another update for Doze in the next couple of hours, where we will showcase a test run.
If you have any further questions, please let us know at any time.

The Geiger tube draws power from a charged capacitor, which is recharged periodically for a fraction of a second. The required power is negligible in normal radiation environments. Despite the charging process, the charging module is completely switched off. Most of the time, Doze is in sleep mode and only wakes up when a particle is detected.

Könnt ihr über usb c bitte eine serielle console oder irgendeine andere Schnittstelle implementieren? Ich würde den Dose gern an Home Assistant hängen. Wäre sowas möglich?

das ist eine sehr gute Idee. Leider wird Doze diese Funktion im Auslieferungszustand nicht bieten. Jedoch gibt es eine Möglichkeit, eine serielle Schnittstelle über USB herzustellen. Das könnte ein Projekt für die Backer Community werden, sobald wir Doze ausgeliefert haben:

Wir haben uns dazu entschieden, den Bootloader Micronucleus für Doze zu nutzen. Dieser ermöglicht den Upload von Programmen via USB. Eine serielle Schnittstelle via USB (genauer gesagt V-USB) über das Programm ist somit nicht mehr möglich. Allerdings können Nutzer auch Programme über eine ISP-Schnittstelle hochladen bzw. ohne den Micronucleus Bootloader. Dafür bietet die Platine entsprechende Kontakte, die mit einem ISP-Programmer (z.B. USBtinyISP) verbunden werden können. Mit dieser Methode sollte es möglich sein, eine serielle Schnittstelle über USB im Programm bereitzustellen.
Ich hoffe, meine Antwort hilft und wir sind offen für weitere Ideen aus der Community.
Q: Can you implement a serial console or any other interface? I would like to connect Doze to Home Assistant. Would it be possible?

we think this is a very good idea. Unfortunately, Doze does not have this feature. But there is a way to allow Doze to do serial communication. It could be a good project for our Backer community with Doze in their hands:

We decided to use the bootloader Micronucleus for Doze which allows users to upload programs simply via USB. With this feature, a serial interface via USB (more precise V-USB) cannot be implemented in the program anymore. However, users will have the chance to upload own programs directly over the ISP interface, that means without the Micronucleus bootloader. The PCB design of Doze offers free connection pads that can be directly connected to an ISP programmer (e.g. USBTinyISP). With this method, it should be possible to implement serial communication via USB in the program.
I hope my answer helps you. We are glad to know if the community has other ideas.

What's the difference between Dr. Bartha Toys and Scratch?

Great question! DrBartha Toys brings block programming into the physical world, while Scratch is a screen-based programming language. Both are Turing-complete and designed for educational purposes, but instead of dragging blocks on a screen, our system lets kids stack coding bricks to create real, tangible programs. Plus, our interpreter is written in Python, and programs built with DrBartha Toys can also be translated to Scratch, bridging physical and digital programming environments.
Can't wait to see where this goes :)
Thanks! Excited to share the journey with you! 😊

Can you confirm what type of Z belts this printer is using?

For this style of printer, the Z belts are important, and those look like white steel belted GT2 belts, not the fibre reinforced Gates ones everyone builds Voron's with. Those steel belted belts seem like a great idea. Then you tension them, and let them sit. The steel gets a deformation in it, and you end up with a bump in the belts. That bump causes inconsistent Z motion when it goes over the drive gear or idlers on the Z axis.

Hi Robert, You’re absolutely correct—the Z-axis belt is crucial for performance. All the belts in the Thinker X400 are made from fiber-reinforced Gates materials, ensuring durability and reliability. Thank you for your insight!

1. We offer a free one-year ChatGPT subscription, and after that period, you’ll have the option to either continue using our subscription for an additional fee or use your own.

2. We’ve tested various AI models (ChatGPT and Claude), and currently, we’re using ChatGPT due to its high-quality output and frequent updates. We’ve received several inquiries about switching AI models, and our team is actively exploring how we can implement this feature.

3. FaceAI can understand and respond in Serbian, but please note that it’s not as advanced as it is in English. While FaceAI can handle general conversations in Serbian, more complex topics may not be as accurate. However, we’re actively working on enhancing its capabilities to support deeper discussions.

4. Great question, you clearly understand the technology! For optimal performance and longevity, it's best to use non-mineralized water in the FaceAI device, as this helps prevent buildup and ensures it works smoothly for longer.
5. Thanks for the suggestion! We've actually considered adding essential oils ourselves and think it's a great idea. We might include it during the campaign!
6. As for water replacement, non-mineralized water can be used for up to two months, while purified water should be changed every 2-3 weeks to maintain optimal performance.
7. Thanks for noting! Yes, we’ve made it easy to activate FaceAI—just say “Hey FaceAI” to get started, and deactivate it by saying “Bye bye FaceAI.”
If you have any thoughts or questions, feel free to reach out!

The FaceAI Team

1. There are a few ways to activate FaceAI: 1) Simply say “Hey FaceAI,” 2) Use the app, or 3) Press the button on the device.

Hi Marcus! Thank you for your interest in FaceAI!
1. FaceAI currently supports over 20 languages. You can easily change the language through the FaceAI app.

2. Sales support will be managed through a dedicated team, primarily via email, to handle inquiries and orders efficiently. If you have any questions, feel free to contact us at faceai.team@gmail.com.

3. You can ask a wide range of questions, including general information, facts, advice, as well as queries related to learning and entertainment. If FaceAI can’t answer your question, it will ask for clarification or suggest looking up the information online.

Hi Riky, Great question! The Feiyu SCORP M2 and DJI RS 4 Mini are both fantastic compact gimbals, but the SCORP M2 really shines with its versatility and smart features. It's AI-powered tracking works with any phone or app, making it a game-changer for livestreams, video calls, and third-party camera apps. Plus, it supports multiple device types—smartphones, mirrorless cameras, compact cameras, and action cameras—so you won’t need separate gimbals for different gear.

On top of that, the SCORP M2 unlocks more creative possibilities with motion-lapse, hyper-lapse, 9-square panorama, and Space Mode (360-degree rotation). Its ergonomic T-shaped handle ensures comfort during long shoots, while fast charging (just 1.9 hours for a full charge) gives you over 10 hours of use. The built-in OLED touchscreen and magic wheel also make adjustments seamless and precise.
If you’re after a gimbal that’s powerful, intuitive, and designed for both smartphones and cameras, the SCORP M2 is an excellent pick!

fipsy-fpga-v2-the-breakout-board-for-beg.comment: As someone with no FPGA experience.
Why would I want to learn to work with an FPGA?
What are some things I can do with this particular item.
Is there a cool project I can do with this and say software development (like a todo app or something I can code myself) ?
FPGAs give you the ability to learn about electronics at a lower level than microcontrollers. Imagine taking your ‘software-style’ algorithm and running it more quickly on dedicated logic circuits.
A really cool example is this VGA Pong demo, where you can combine both hardware and circuit design: https://www.fipsyfpga.com/learning/learning-projects/vga-pong/

We are working to add more examples, such as other educational game frameworks and HDMI protocol examples. Please take a look at the current list of example projects here: https://www.fipsyfpga.com/learning/learning-projects/

When you are building with FPGAs you are designing both the algorithm logic, and the hardware-level design. It’s very similar to building your own kind of CPU. You can do custom things better, for example many analog to digital signal processors use FPGAs because they can handle a stream of real-time information better than microcontrollers/CPUs. The Fipsy FPGA V2 plays well with other devices like the ESP32, and would let you build any IoT system you want.
You went with quite the long backing period for this campaign, any plans to potentially shorten that down at some point or start production early?

We are as excited as you are to get the Fipsy V2 in the hands of makers, learners and creatives! I want to be conservative with what we are committing to. During the launch of the original Fipsy V1, we were able to deliver a majority of the boards over a month ahead of schedule. But for now, we’ll stick to our stated timeline (and work behind the scenes to accelerate this as much as possible). One goal of this project is to introduce this to the market so folks never need to wait for ‘one-off’ campaigns again.
Okay, thanks, good luck

Wondering what this means. I want to learn more about fpga and understanding this would help me. Does it mean, 'on chip' or through some sort of gpio? or... something i dont know how to articulate. clarification appreciated.

When you work with electrical signals, you can have one or more wires carrying the data. These wires switch between ground and full voltage, representing the zeros and ones. Protocols are how data packets are sent over these wires, and stored on the chip. With microcontrollers, you usually have libraries that hide how the data actually flows. With an FPGA, you can better learn how these protocols actually work. The Fipsy FPGA V2 allows you to design data structures like registers and wires for on-chip storage and processing, while controlling the GPIO. Please take a look at the MIDI ‘module flow diagram’ on our Basic Theory educational page: https://www.fipsyfpga.com/learning/brief-theory/
Stumbled on this and backed it. Looking at your website, you seem to push Lattice Diamond as the software back end. Last time I tried FPGAs it was Xilinx, and the software was - monstrous.
I heard the Lattice chips are now supported by open source software. Is that an option? The software experience could make or break the FPGA learning process.

The Lattice Chip family that is best supported by Open Source IDEs to my knowledge are the iCE40 and ECP5 Chip Families. We are instead using the MachXO2 Family, which helps to keep the cost down for beginners. However, MachXO2 is not yet supported by the open source FPGA tool chains that I'm aware of yet. I bet if we can grow a bigger hobbyist FPGA community, that would change.

There are plans to get MachXO2 into the existing open source tools, but I'm not aware of anything other than Lattice Diamond for creating the final bitstream/.jed file. That said, you can create the Verilog in a wide range of IDEs (coding and compiling to a bit stream can be done in separate environments), and use Lattice Diamond (which is still free) for just the last compilation step.
The open source projects to look at are:
https://icestudio.io/ as an IDE and F4PGA as a bitstream compiler - https://f4pga.org/
If anybody knows of other Open Source products that play well with Lattice MachX02 Families (or HDL/Verilog generally) - please send me a DM and I'll update the documentation.
Thank you for being a backer, and helping to bring FPGAs to the general electronics community.
https://icestudio.io/

Never really got very far with v1 because I was hoping for more tutorials especially around an hdmi board. ivycable-p6-fast-charging-magnetic-cable.comment: Matt, I backed this because it seemed very interesting. I have backed before. What is difference between this and the previous version?
Dear Gregory,
The main differences between the IVYCABLE P6 and the previous generation IVYCABLE are as follows:

1. **Faster Charging Speed**: The IVYCABLE P6 supports PD60W fast charging, allowing it to quickly charge smartphones, laptops, and other devices that support the PD fast charging protocol, such as gaming consoles. This means that one IVYCABLE P6 can meet the fast charging or standard charging needs of nearly all electronic devices.

2. **Smarter Design**: The IVYCABLE P6 features our proprietary solution. During pass-through fast charging (when devices like smartphones are charged through the IVYCABLE connected to a charger), it functions as a standard charging cable, directly transferring all the power from the charger to the device. Once the device is fully charged, the IVYCABLE P6 then draws 5V (Max. 2.4A) from the charger to recharge its built-in battery until it is fully charged.
3. **More Portable**: The IVYCABLE P6 is lighter and more compact than its predecessor, making it easier to hold or carry in your pocket, providing a more convenient experience.

4. **Multi-functional Design**: The IVYCABLE P6 resembles a standard three-section staff (a traditional Chinese martial arts weapon). In emergency situations, it can be used for self-defense, adding an extra layer of utility.

Thank you once again for your support and for raising such important questions. I hope the above answers provide you with a clearer and more intuitive understanding of the differences between the IVYCABLE P6 and previous products!
Sincerely & B.regards
Matt

Mr.Sebastian, thank you very much for so kindly responds!
Thank you for such a representative question.
When used as a power bank, the Ivycable P6 has a rated capacity of 3000mAh (11.4W), fully complying with airline regulations. Its maximum input and output power are both 5V&2.4A (12W).
This design maximizes the charging efficiency for devices while minimizing energy loss during the boost conversion process.

In passthrough mode (when connected to a wall outlet while charging a device), the Ivycable P6 functions as a fast-charging cable that supports PD 60W (20V & 3A). When fast charging, Ivycable automatically stops charging its built-in battery and directly powers the connected device.
The advantage of this design is that during PD 60W charging, Ivycable does not generate heat, ensuring safety.

Hi Clownstrike,
Yes, the Ivycable P6 only has one specification: Type-C male to Type-C female. If an extension cable is needed, the specification must be Type-C female to Type-C male.

Hi! Came across this in a newsletter and thought the idea was so cool. Could i just check when you guys claim 3000mAh does that refer to the effective capacity? Eg some 5k mAh power banks can probably only output effectively 3k due to heat losses etc
Hi Ray，

That’s a very good question! As you’ve noted regarding heat loss, the actual capacity delivered to the phone from the battery will have some level of loss, with the typical conversion rate around 70%. However, depending on the circuit design, the thickness of the PCB copper traces, and the cross-sectional area of the wires, the conversion efficiency can vary. Of course, there are other factors that influence efficiency, so the conversion rate may differ. The rated capacity of Ivycable P6 is 3000mAh, which is its minimum capacity. Based on our actual tests, Ivycable P6 can fully charge an iPhone 12 Mini once. Since the standard capacity of the iPhone 12 Mini is 2227mAh, the conversion efficiency of Ivycable P6 can reach 74%, which is more than sufficient for a day’s worth of outdoor backup power for the phone. Thank you very much for sharing such a professional question here, and once again, thank you for your support of Ivycable P6!

Honestly I have to commend you guys on such a detailed explanation to my concerns. I hope others can see this thread too and to me it’s a sign of clear understanding of the product and actual prototyping and testing, and you are right I would think ~2.2k is sufficient as a backup power source. Hope you have a successful campaign!
I'd need a longer cable, would there be a chance of you making a longer extension cables, or can we use more that one extension cable (daisy chains)??
Oh well, 1m it is then. Could you connect two 1m cables together?
Hi Nicky,
Thank you very much for comment!

1. A 2-meter-long extension cable typically experiences a voltage drop of nearly 0.5V under normal conditions when current is transmitted from one end to the other. If an Ivycable P6 is added in series, which uses PCB copper traces instead of copper wires, the voltage drop will become significantly larger, making it difficult to meet the voltage requirements of the PD protocol.

2. Such a long extension cable can also cause the CC signal handshake and transmission between the charger and the phone or computer to become unstable during PD fast charging. This instability can ultimately result in charging efficiency failing to meet the standards of PD fast charging.
Therefore, it is highly discouraged to use two 1-meter extension cables connected in series!
If you really need a 2-meter-long extension cable, I suggest searching for one that meets the following requirements:
• The conductor is made of 20 AWG pure copper or enameled wire.
• The cable has a shielding layer.
• The Type-C connector features 24 pins.
Such an extension cable can maintain signal integrity over a 2-meter distance and ensure the voltage drop remains within acceptable limits.
For you reference!

Hello David Hardy! The Nano Duo galvo laser can engrave photos on 4x4-inch slate or tile, but achieving engraving times under 1 minute—especially around 30 seconds—may be challenging, depending on the complexity of the image and the settings used. For hard materials like slate or tile, an infrared laser is preferred, as it provides better contrast and speed than diode lasers. If you have any other questions or need further guidance, feel free to reach out! Thank you for your support!

lshow-plasma-deodorizer-stop-body-odor-a.comment: Hi Magdi,

Thank you very much for your valuable feedback. We fully understand your concern about the actual effectiveness of the product. The issue of body odor does vary from person to person, and your cautious attitude is very reasonable. We have test reports to prove the effect of plasma. If you need it, we can send it to your email.
I did send you an email, but I don't know why you didn't receive it. I have already sent it many times.
Hi Magdi,
Thank you for your question.
We have experimental research papers that we can send to your email. Please send me your email.
Meanwhile, here are several authoritative papers and related statements on the elimination of odors by low-temperature plasma:
1. Antibacterial and Deodorizing Effects of Cold Atmosphere Plasma Applied Electronic Deodoriant
• Publication date: February 6, 2024
• Source: Nature

Core content: The application of cold atmospheric plasma in electronic deodorizers was studied, and it was found that it has dual effects of antibacterial and deodorizing. Experiments have shown that cold plasma has a high degradation efficiency for volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and can effectively inhibit bacterial growth, thereby reducing the production of odors.
2. Research progress on low-temperature plasma removal of VOCs technology
• Publication date: December 11, 2024
• Source: Chemical Engineering Paper

• Core content: Introduces the principle and application of low-temperature plasma for removing volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Research has shown that low-temperature plasma can efficiently degrade VOCs and eliminate odors through high-energy electron excitation and chemical reactions. Meanwhile, the article also explores the coupling application of low-temperature plasma with other technologies such as catalytic oxidation, further improving the degradation efficiency of pollutants.
3. A combined process of non thermal plasma and a low cost mineral adsorbent for VOC removal and odor mitigation in emissions of organic waste treatment plants
• Author: Dobslaw D,Ortlinglehaus O,Dobslaw C
• Publication time: 2018

• Core content: Studied the combination of non thermal plasma and low-cost mineral adsorbents for the treatment of VOCs and odors emitted from organic waste treatment plants. The results indicate that this combination process can effectively remove VOCs and significantly reduce the intensity of odors.
4. Influence of operational conditions on the performance of non thermal plasma technology for VOC pollution control
• Author: Adelodun A A
• Publication time: 2020

• Core content: Explored the impact of operating conditions on the treatment of VOCs pollution using non thermal plasma technology. Research has shown that factors such as gas concentration, residence time, and discharge parameters have a significant impact on the degradation efficiency and odor elimination effect of VOCs.
5. Post polymerization catalytic degradation of tower using atmosphere double dielectric barrier discharge combined with MnO based catalysts
• Author: Zhang S,Liang J Y,Yu X Y,et al.
• Publication time: 2021

Core content: The post plasma catalytic degradation effect of toluene by atmospheric dual dielectric barrier discharge combined with MnO based catalyst was studied. The results showed that the synergistic effect of plasma and catalyst significantly improved the degradation efficiency of toluene and the selectivity of CO ₂, while reducing the generation of odors.
6. Volatile Organic Compounds Degradation by Non Thermal Plasma: A Review
• Author: He Y,Shen J,Alharbi N S,Chen C
• Publication date: 2023

• Core content: This article reviews the research progress on non thermal plasma degradation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). The article provides a detailed analysis of the degradation mechanism, influencing factors, and coupling applications with other technologies of non thermal plasma. Research has shown that non thermal plasma technology has the advantages of high efficiency and energy saving in eliminating VOCs and odors.
7. Non thermal plasma coupled with a wet scrubber for removing odorous VOCs
• Author: Kim M R,Jeon W,Kim S
• Publication date: 2023

Core content: The study investigated the effectiveness of coupling non thermal plasma with wet scrubbers in removing odorous volatile organic compounds (VOCs). The results indicate that this combination process can effectively remove odorous VOCs and exhibits good adaptability when dealing with complex gas components.
8. Key Technologies for Low Temperature Plasma Purification of Volatile Organic Compounds
• Authors: Yao Shuiliang, Zhang Xuming, Lu Hao
• Publication time: 2020

Core content: Explored the key technologies for low-temperature plasma purification of volatile organic compounds, including discharge methods, reactor design, and optimization of operating parameters. Research has shown that low-temperature plasma technology has significant advantages in treating low concentration and high air volume VOCs, and can effectively eliminate odors.
Do you have scientific results as proof of its effectiveness?
Hi Roy,
We have a patent certificate for a plasma generating device. At present, plasma is also widely used in the medical field. Please refer the explanation on our detail page.
If you have any question, please send to this email : lshow0602@outlook.com

Our design is set and certifications are on track as planned. The MinVerse was designed with manufacturing in mind, so moving from small to large-scale production won’t require significant changes. Key Advantages of MinVerse Over Touch X
✅ More Compact & Portable – MinVerse is significantly lighter (1.2kg vs. 3.2kg) and has a smaller footprint, making it easier to integrate into workspaces or carry around.
✅ Comparable Workspace in a Smaller Device – Despite being more compact, MinVerse offers a comparable or even larger effective workspace (145 x 330 x 250 mm vs. Touch X’s 355 x 228 x 180 mm).

✅ Modern Connectivity & Expandability – The MinVerse supports USB-C and wireless stylus input, with plans for a wireless mouse, making it future-proof compared to Touch X’s traditional USB-only connection.

While Touch X has been a standard in haptic feedback, the MinVerse provides equivalent or superior performance in a smaller, lighter, and more modern package—at half the price. With comparable workspace, better expandability, and high-end force feedback, MinVerse is the smarter choice for those looking for affordability without compromising on quality. 🚀

So I asked ChatGPT this: What would be the most special feeling to feel with the Inverse3?
Answer from ChatGPT :

The Inverse3 by Haply Robotics, with its ability to apply precise haptic forces, can simulate a wide range of immersive sensations. Here are some of the most unique and special sensations you could experience with this device:
1. Floating or Modified Gravity Sensation
• Description: Simulate a low-gravity environment (like the Moon), zero-gravity (space), or high gravity (a massive planet).
• Feeling: A light force or counter-effect that seems to suspend the object, or alternatively, a strong pull downward.
• Use case:
o Training for astronauts or microgravity experiments.
o Immersive VR simulations where the user explores extraterrestrial environments.
2. Dynamic Non-Newtonian Fluids
• Description: Simulate materials like Oobleck or quicksand, where resistance depends on movement speed.
• Feeling: A resistance that increases with force or speed, creating the impression of plunging hands into a reactive, living material.
• Use case:
o Scientific or educational explorations to demonstrate physical concepts.
o Immersive, interactive experiences that intrigue the user.
3. Realistic Texture of a Living Object
• Description: Simulate the sensation of a heartbeat, breathing, or muscular contractions of a living organism.
• Feeling: A rhythmic vibration or movement that mimics biological patterns (e.g., heart rate or lung expansion/contraction).
• Use case:
o Medical simulations or training to feel organs in a virtual surgery environment.
o Emotional immersive experiences to "feel" the "life" of an object.
4. Magnetic Friction
• Description: Simulate a resistance or magnetic attraction, as if two magnets were interacting at a distance.
• Feeling: A variable force depending on the position or proximity of a virtual object, mimicking magnetic attraction or repulsion.
• Use case:
o Visualizing magnetic interactions for physics education.
o Immersive experiences where the user feels invisible forces.
5. Stretching and Snapping Elastic Bands
• Description: Simulate the sensation of an elastic band being stretched under tension and snapping back when released.
• Feeling: A resistance that gradually increases, followed by a rapid release (a "snap").
• Use case:
o Games or puzzles where users manipulate virtual ropes or elastic bands.
o Simulations of slingshots or archery.
6. Simulated Electric Shocks
• Description: A rapid, "tingling" haptic vibration mimicking an electric shock.
• Feeling: Short, sudden, repetitive haptic pulses to simulate a zap or electrifying contact.
• Use case:
o Simulations of dangerous environments (without real risk).
o Sci-fi or VR experiences (e.g., handling electrical equipment).
7. Hyper-Realistic Collisions
• Description: Simulate realistic physical impacts (e.g., touching a ball or bumping into a hard or soft surface).
• Feeling: A brief but powerful force with a quick rebound, giving the impression of a real collision.
• Use case:
o Sports games where the user hits a ball or interacts with physical objects.
o Industrial simulations to test impacts or collisions.
8. Dynamic Vortex or Suction
• Description: Simulate a force pulling the user toward a center, like a vortex, water whirlpool, or black hole.
• Feeling: A constant force that varies in intensity based on the user’s distance from the vortex center.
• Use case:
o VR simulations to explore natural phenomena (whirlpools, black holes).
o Immersive experiences where users struggle against a suction force.
9. Progressive Friction (Dynamic Braking or Resistance)
• Description: Simulate the sensation of braking or sliding on different surfaces (sand, ice, asphalt, etc.).
• Feeling: A force that dynamically changes based on speed or the simulated surface.
• Use case:
o Driving simulators where the user feels the braking effect.
o Interactive experiences where different terrains affect resistance.
10. Complex Pulses and Waves
• Description: Simulate complex vibratory patterns, such as waves or pulses at varying frequencies.
• Feeling: A series of undulating vibrations that give the impression of manipulating energetic phenomena (sound waves, currents).
• Use case:
o Acoustic or physical simulations.
o Immersive experiences where the user "feels" music or energetic waves.
Ultimate Sensation to Try: Combining Multiple Effects
Imagine an experience where:
• You plunge your hand into a living fluid (non-Newtonian with a biological feel).
• Feel rhythmic vibrations mimicking a beating heart underwater.
• Struggle against a suction force simulating a vortex.
• Once pulled out, a snapping elastic effect adds a dramatic final sensation.
Conclusion

The most "special" sensation depends on the goal: educational, immersive, artistic, or experimental. The Inverse3 excels in its ability to combine dynamic haptic forces to create ultra-realistic and unique experiences. If you'd like to explore any of these ideas in more detail (e.g., implementation), let me know, and I can assist further!

Interesting take, ChatGPT! Honestly, we're going to really be focusing on some of the UX interactions in a touchAPI because 3D UX is novel and when you throw forces and vibrations in the mix it becomes truely the wild west of user interaction. We're calling this the FUI. Force user interaction. The goal is to make the FUI for the user intuitive and to enhance, not invent, their workflow. More to come but we're into the authoring the API phase. After this we're taking some of the UX demos we put together for CES and are going to connect some of the authoring tools and FUIs that we designed into a plugin for blender. Some others suffer with this as time and heat converge, and that typically results in a hit to performance, at least on an iPhone 16 Pro Max.

In our testing the PicoDrive appears as available for ProRes recording (on the native camera app) the moment you plug it in, at most there's a slight delay of 1-2s? Unlike other M.2 SSD enclosures which can peak up to 10W under load causing instability, the maximum power draw for the PicoDrive is only 3.5W, well under the 4.5W limit supported by the iPhone 15/16 (https://support.apple.com/en-us/105099), no external power necessary.

While you can use magsafe if you would like to charge as you film, there's also a 100W Power Data Splitter available as an add-on which would enable direct USBC pass through charging. I would advise against charging with magsafe though as in my experience it results in greater heat output...
I've personally used the the PicoDrive for 4k ProRes recordings of ~1h, its rated for 40Gbps - over 4x higher than the 10Gbps theoretical maximum bandwidth of an iPhone.
I did include power data splitter, though it’s not always convenient and MagSafe is okay for a short period. Totally agree, heat can be a challenge.

In my eyes this is a missed opportunity.
With a CPU with more PCIe lanes and dual channel RAM and an Oculink or Thunderbolt 4 or 5 port in the same case, this would have been a killer device!
The perfect companion to my large 6 bay (3.5" HDD) NAS.
As it is, I'm torn whether I actually want/need the N2 or use the money for something else.
Please don't get me wrong. I fully understand why you designed the N2 the way you did and it is good as it is for many potential customers.
But I'm simply not sure anymore whether or not it is good (enough) for my use case.
No worries at all—we truly appreciate discussions like this and value having a platform where we can engage directly with users.

The device you envision sounds fantastic, but implementing it within the N1/N2 hardware structure would be quite challenging. As you’ve noticed, the N2 is designed to be extremely compact and operates with minimal noise. However, a more powerful CPU would require significantly enhanced cooling, which in turn could introduce noise—something we’ve always tried to balance in our development process.

This is one of the key challenges we constantly face when designing NAS devices, and it highlights just how much potential there still is to explore in this field. We’re excited about the future and hope to get closer to the kind of product you envision.
Thanks again for sharing your thoughts—we truly appreciate the feedback!
Hi, first I want to shout out how awesome products you are developing!
Now it's time for my questions:

1. I would like to run Proxmox on a Lincstation N2. From what I found I can achieve that by just installing the OS on a one of drives (assumption based on research about N1) . Is it that simple and will a new OS have full access to hardware?
2. Where can I find some kind of BIOS documentation for Lincstation N2? I would like to check if it will support features like - return previous state after power loss.
Don't you think 16GB of RAM are bit too little to do anything useful with any hypervisor?
Like always - it depends.

I wouldn't complain if it had more RAM. But, in my case, it's enough. I'm already running Proxmox on an HP EliteDesk 800 G3 mini 65W with 16GB of RAM. And I'm able to host there all that I need (HomeAssistant, Frigate, NextCloud, Immich, PiHole, VPN, media server, and a few light LXCs = ~12GB).

Available storage slots are what I miss in my setup (I tried to use M.2 to multiple SATA adapter, but it is not stable solution). So I started to look for NAS. And here comes Lincstation N2 - NAS that can replace my home server. I'm still impressed that (from what I found) it will have similar performance to my HP with much less power consumption for only 309$
Marcin and Stefan, thank you both for this insightful discussion!

We truly appreciate these conversations because you each represent different types of NAS users. When designing our products, we constantly navigate trade-offs between ROM, RAM, CPU, network ports, power consumption, cooling, noise levels, and overall value. In making these choices, we always strive to strike a balance based on the majority of user needs.

For example, the N2 is a great fit for Marcin, offering practical performance, energy efficiency, and affordability. However, for power users like Stefan, who require higher performance, the N100 CPU’s official memory limit of 16GB may not be sufficient. It's challenging to create a single product that meets everyone’s needs perfectly, but we are committed to continuously exploring deeper user demands, balancing these factors, and offering more choices in the future.
Thank you both for your support and engagement.
Curious why the s1 didn’t get the 10gb port or the n100 like the n2?
Thank you for your question.

Firstly, we chose to equip the S1 with dual 2.5G ports because this configuration offers greater flexibility. While a 10GbE port provides high-speed data transfer, 2.5G is sufficient for many regular users and offers a better cost-performance balance.
Secondly, regarding the CPU, we selected the N97 for the S1 because it delivers superior performance compared to the N100 used in the N2.
These choices were made based on market feedback, and we will continue to offer more options in the future based on customer needs.
N2 deliver to Singapore?

Hi Tom, thanks for your question! The N2 has been upgraded in multiple aspects to enhance both silent operation and heat dissipation.

First, the fan now operates in an optimized smart mode, meaning it only increases speed under heavy workloads while remaining silent during idle periods. Additionally, we’ve added ventilation holes at the bottom to improve airflow and overall cooling efficiency.
Furthermore, we’ve refined the thermal management system with advanced materials like nano-carbon and high-quality thermal silicone to enhance heat dissipation from every detail.
Hope this helps!
Silent doesn’t mean the fan will completely stop spinning. It just means the fan speed will be low, around 3000 RPM or less, making the noise almost inaudible.
"better N97" chip? In what way? Compared to what?
AFAIK the N97 has better peak performance, but the N100 is less energy hungry / more energy efficient (PBP 6W vs 12W of the N97).
So if you don't need the additional compute power, the N100 may be the better choice.
Thank you all for your questions and discussion.
Firstly, to clarify, the CPU in the S1 is N97, while the N2 uses the N100.

Secondly, in most cases, the system supports Active State Power Management (ASPM). With ERP enabled, the standby power consumption is around 0.5W, and the power consumption in shutdown or sleep mode is around 2W. Regarding NAS power consumption, it's important to note that hard drives significantly impact overall power usage. For a more detailed power consumption analysis, you may refer to third-party reviews.
https://nascompares.com/review/lincstation-n2-nas-review-better-than-the-n1/
https://nascompares.com/review/lincstation-s1-nas-review/
Lastly, thank you for your suggestion. We are indeed continuously working to optimize our products to better meet everyone's needs.
For the first question, in theory, it can be used, but we don’t highly recommend it. Additionally, we haven’t tested a 16TB 2.5-inch SATA SSD, so we cannot guarantee its performance or compatibility.
For the second question, while we have sufficient RAM and ROM, we officially partner only with Unraid.
Will SN850X 8TB nvme drives fit?
Yes, the SN850X 8TB NVMe drives are supported.
The N2 supports:
2.5-inch SATA HDDs/SSDs (max height: 9.5mm)
2280 NVMe SSDs (up to 8TB each)
The S1 supports:
3.5-inch SATA HDDs (up to 24TB each)
2.5-inch SATA HDDs/SSDs (fits in 3.5" bays with adapters)
2280 NVMe SSDs (up to 8TB each)
Will N2 include wifi like the N1 Had

Thanks for your question! Although the N1 features WiFi and Bluetooth, many users have told us that these features are not useful since they cannot be used under the Unraid system. Therefore, the N2 does not come with WiFi or Bluetooth.

Thank you for your question. Here is a more detailed explanation of the steps for using the Unraid license.
Start with a free 1-month trial (register on Unraid’s website).

Post-12 months: Continue using your current version indefinitely.

Could you briefly explain the difference for the types of lenses? I'm interested in adding some to my pledge, but would like to know better the difference between them and pros and cons, please.
Hi Gabriel
The laser protective lens is designed to prevent dust and splashes from damaging the focusing lens, making it an essential consumable part. It is typically made of quartz with a coated surface.
The focusing lens concentrates parallel light beams into a high-energy density point to achieve a powerful laser beam. It is usually a convex lens made of quartz or silicon.
The collimating lens shapes divergent light into a parallel beam, optimizing beam quality. It is generally made of quartz or crystal.

Are the culminating and focusing lens available as an add-on because they are considered consumable items for the X1Pro, if not why what are they used for?
Hi Z

The focusing lens and collimating lens are available as add-ons and are considered consumables. However, with proper usage, they typically do not wear out quickly—usually requiring replacement every six months to a year. But if the welding gun is accidentally dropped, they may get damaged immediately.

The main function of the focusing lens is to focus the laser beam onto a specific working area, concentrating the laser energy at the welding point. By precisely focusing the laser, welding accuracy and efficiency can be improved.

The role of the collimating lens in the laser welding gun is to convert the divergent laser beam into a parallel beam, reducing the divergence during beam propagation. The collimating lens optimizes the laser beam quality, which benefits subsequent focusing and energy transfer.
Thank you

Based on our bodywork cleaning tests, the maximum width of our cleaning mode is 17mm. On the other hand, because the X1 Pro uses a heat fusion principle during cleaning, the paint on the sheet metal carbonizes and releases a large amount of dust, which is more effective on the metal surface. This is a limitation based on materials. Some specific coatings, such as high-temperature cured oxide layers, are difficult to remove. The third limitation is the cleaning depth. If the corrosion is too deep, repeated cleaning or mechanical grinding may be needed during use.

Thank you for your question, Ianfa!
By your test,for the self-cleaning process, the printer uses both ink and cleaning solution. Here’s the breakdown:
Moisturizing liquid (Total 30ml)
For moisture maintenance, every three days: 20ml per month
For cleaning, every six days: 10ml per month
Ink (Total 30ml)
One cleaning session uses 8ml (3ml color ink, 3ml white ink, 2ml moisturizing solution)
Every six days: 30ml per month (15ml color ink and 15ml white ink)
This ensures the printer heads stay clean while minimizing ink waste.

After exporting your image, convert it to formats like JPEG or PNG... etc, and then import it into XCS. The DPI can be set according to your preference. There are four options available: 720*600 (4 PASS), 720*900 (6 PASS), 720*1200 (8 PASS), and 720*1800 (12 PASS).
